newsitem.title: UK: Oftel says to look at how BIB operates.
newsitem.headline: Oftel says to look at how BIB operates.

text.p: UK telecoms watchdog Oftel said on Wednesday that it would look closely at how a new venture involving British Telecom and BSkyB intends to operate.
But Oftel director-general Don Cruickshank said it was not his job to approve the joint venture.

"It was not my job to approve this joint venture - that is for others including the European Commission. Now the joint venture has been announced, my job is to look at the way they do business," Cruickshank said.
"If the joint venture works in a way which doesn't distort the market, the range of services it offers will be good news for customers," he added.
Cruickshank said that Oftel would monitor developments in a bid to ensure compatibility between digital satellite, digital cable and digital terrestrial delivery platforms.
"Over the coming months I will be watching very closely how this compatibility pledge develops and also at a number of other key issues."

"For example, how to recover the cost of subsidising the set-top box down to around 200 pounds, and how conditional access and the electronic programme guide will apply to all broadcasters and providers of interactive services." BT and BSkyB plan each to take a 32.5 percent stake in BIB, while Midland Bank will have 20 percent and Matsushita 15 percent.
BIB plans to develop interactive services such as home shopping and home banking and subsidise set-top boxes down to a retail price of around 200 stg.
